But it was uncomfortable and yucky wading through water after every shower, and after reporting the problem to management we were told it was a design flaw and nothing could really be done. That said, my husband said that that room was his favorite of all the places we stayed; it certainly was very hip and cool. We found it to be roomy, with a huge walk-in closet that accommodating our (many--too many) pieces of luggage without problem. It was quiet and the bed--built on a slight platform--was comfortable. We would like to go back but if we do, we might inquire about another "deluxe" room, or if the design flaw in the bathroom has been fixed.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent location, very friendly staff, could be home away from home.”
Reviews.Author: TampaHiker
Reviews.Content: This hotel is in the heart of the ancient part of Istanbul (Sultanahmet), just 1/2 block from the Hippodrome and one block from the Blue Mosque. The hotel is small, but has a lobby that is inviting and warm. There is ample comfortable chairs, two fireplaces and a large table with a laptop for guests to use. It also has WIFI which worked in the lobby as well as the rooftop. The rooftop has a spectacular view of the Sultanahmet neighborhood as well as the Blue Mosque. The roof has many chairs and tables and has a bar that serves coffee, beer, wine, mixed drinks and snacks. The rooms are small, but comfortable. The beds were firm and very comfortable. Rooms that face the front of the hotel hear occasional street noise (garbage trucks late at night and other maintenance traffic, but there isn't much traffic on the tiny street). If you are a light sleeper, I recommend a room on the backside of the hotel where it is much quieter. The breakfast is excellent with an abundant choice of bakery goods, cheeses, cereals, yogurt and excellent coffee and tea. This hotel is within walking distance of the Blue Mosque, Haghia Sofia, Hippodrome (and the obelisks), Museum of Turkish and Islamic Arts (next door in the Ibrahim Pasha Palace - I highly recommend this), Topkapi Palace, Archaeological Museum, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, and several hamamis (Turkish Bath). For those who don't mind longer walks, we also walked to Kumkapi (fish market/restaurants) area and along the seawall/balastrade (Kennedy Caddesi) of the Boshphorus to the Galata Bridge.

Reviews.Title: “Location, Location, Location...”
Reviews.Author: Hulivili
Reviews.Content: If you are in Istanbul for the first time, and especially if your time is limited - i.e. weekend or so - this is your place. The hotel is located right next door to the main sights of Istanbul (Blue Mosque etc.). The next best thing about this hotel is the service. The staff was very professional, enthusiastic and courteous - just fantastic, they helped me so much with everything. The buffet breakfast was really good. The rooms were a bit small but nicely decorated. If you have choice, try to get a room not facing the street, which can be a little noisy during the day.

Reviews.Title: “mixed feelings”
Reviews.Author: petalPerth
Reviews.Content: The location is great and the roof top terrace is lovely although some shade would be great in the heat of the day. The bedroom was very cramped and it was a suite. You could hardly walk past the side of the bed. The bathroom was tiny and needing repair. Shower head broken so water squirted everywhere and the shower drain had half a broken tile covering the drain pipe. I thought the standard of cleanliness could also be improved. The staff were helpful and friendly, the breakfast delicious, free tea and coffee and overall the place did have a certain charm

Reviews.Title: “A lovely spot from which to explore Istanbul”
Reviews.Author: Monica19
Reviews.Content: This was our first trip to Istanbul and chose Ibrahim Pasha based on guidebook recommendations, a look at the website, and traveler reviews on Trip Advisor. We weren't disappointed. Upon our arrival at almost midnight, we found that the rooftop terrace was open every night till 1:00 a.m. for drinks. We were quite tired, but decided to go up anyway. What a perfect way to be introduced to Istanbul. We looked out over the Blue Mosque lit up in the night and had Funda, our lovely bartender for the evening, make us a cocktail to have while sitting there drinking in the beauty of the mosque and the Bosphorus beyond. Our room was a good size, and though it looked out over the main street, was very quiet, a big plus for someone like me who is a light sleeper. Still, be prepared to hear the call to prayer wherever you stay in Istanbul at some point near dawn. The furnishings and set up were sleek and modern but with charming old world touches. A full, delicious breakfast was included in the price of the room and I looked forward every morning to the excellent coffee, fresh squeezed juice and various things to eat to fuel our day of sightseeing. What I liked best about the hotel were its staff and its location. Staying here, we were close to all the sights one wants to witness in Sultanahmet. And everyone who worked at the hotel whom we dealt with was attentive, helpful, and very friendly. The two recommendations we were given for dinner turned out to be excellent choices for what we were looking for, so that was a plus as well. Overall, I would say if you need a charming place to stay in Istanbul where you can relax and enjoy some quiet from the hubbub of the city, this is the place to stay.

Reviews.Title: “We will always remember our stay at Ibrahim Pasha”
Reviews.Author: honey85
Reviews.Content: From the minute we arrived, we felt welcome. The hotel is considered a "boutique" hotel with only about 30 rooms. It is extremely cozy. The staff were very welcoming and helpful orienting us to our stay in Istanbul. The rooms were small by US standards but quiet, and the beds were very comfortable. The bathrooms were also quite small - almost too small - but clean and with plenty of hot water. The hotel was really well situated - easy walking distance to the blue mosque, Aya Sofia and the Topkapi palace. And the traditional Turkish breakfasts were delicious. The spectacular view from the terrace overlooked the bosphorous and the blue mosque. We will look back on our stay very fondly.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderfull hotel at a perfect location”
Reviews.Author: Edwin_Vanessa
Reviews.Content: We stayed in a deluxe room, which offered a balcony, shower/bath, seating area and a separate room for hanging your clothes. Great room for a citytrip. Clean and cosy. The location, on a quiet street radiating from the Hippodrome, is perfect. All the main tourist attractions (Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Cisterne and Topkapi Palace) are within a 10 minute walk. Breakfast buffet was nice with typical Turkish ingredients as well as European. all fresh and of great quality. The terrace on the roof is a great place to realax after a 'sightseeing' day with a great view of the Blue Mosque and the Bosporus / Sea of Marmara. The staff is professional, courteous and very helpful. Their suggestions of where to eat or how to reach certain destinations are fantastic. We'd recommend Ibraim Pasha to anyone looking for it's central location, comfort and great service!

Reviews.Title: “Stylish charm with perfect location”
Reviews.Author: Arne-Thorbeck
Reviews.Content: This hotel is a small gem with the perfect location in Sultanamet. The (deluxe) rooms we had was very stylish, and seemed to be renovated very recently. A very kind staff helps you with reservations and advice on what to see (and not) in Istanbul. We will definitly come back.

Reviews.Title: “hospitality personified”
Reviews.Author: broombank
Reviews.Content: It is difficult to be too complimentary about the Ibrahim Pasha. Of all the hotels we have ever stayed in it must rank as the friendliest and best organised. The staff are committed, dedicated and helpful without exception. Although the standard double rooms are small they are comfortable and well organised. The hotel is very quiet even when full, and the revamped foyer is homely and comfortable with two wood fires burning when its cold outside. Breakfast is a delight - well stocked varied and with lots of little touches like home made cakes every day. There is a constant supply of tea and coffee on tap which can be served on the roof terrace when its warm. Finally the location is truly excellent with so many interesting things to see nearby. There is also easy access to the Grand Bazaar and to the tramline to connect to Beyoglu and Taksim easily and cheaply. This is my second trip and my wife's first . We would love to go back at any opportunity.

Reviews.Title: “Turkish Delight at the Ibrahim Pasha Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Hoolit
Reviews.Content: We were a foursome staying in two delux rooms, which offered quite different ameneties, eg, largish/smallish, balcony/no balcony, shower/bath, seating area/none. But we were all happy with the room we had. The location, on a quiet street radiating from the Hippodrome, was perfect: a great place to pop back for a break and sit by the fire with a drink or munch Turkish delight. Breakfast buffet was plentiful and orange juice worth the extra 5 lira: it would be wonderful to have it on the rooftop orea in summer, with its view of the Blue Mosque. All the staff were professional, courteous and very helpful. Their suggestions of where to eat were fantastic. We'd recommend Ibraim Pasha to anyone looking for charm, comfort and great service in the Sultanahmet area.

Reviews.Title: “Charming, simple, small hotel with friendly staff in center of Sultanahmet.”
Reviews.Author: washbrol
Reviews.Content: Hotel: The Ibrahim Pasha Hotel is a small, charming hotel staffed by a few friendly employees. The hotel has a small casual inviting lobby and rooms are spread a few to a floor up 4-5 floors. Roof terrace was closed for construction at the time of our stay, but I imagine it would have been nice. Room: Very small room (in our case, with 2 single beds, as requested) including small bathroom. Small plasma TV. In-room safe was good for our passports, money, etc. Location: Tucked into a small street in the center of Istanbul's tourist-site-rich Sultanahmet neighborhood. Only meters away is the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, ancient underground cisterns, etc. Staff: Friendly small team. Willing to open the front doors (locked during the night) when we came back late from Istanbul nightlife or got up for a very early departure.

Reviews.Title: “Location,location,location”
Reviews.Author: SJaneSeattle_WA
Reviews.Content: The deluxe rooms were lovely and comfortable with powerful air conditioning. The deluxe baths were lovely and clean (probably due to being new). We had no other service issues at all. A daily tip on the bed insured fresh towels when needed. Please note that the beds are very low to the floor and may be challenging for some people. We are agile 60 somethings and laughed each day when we tried to get up from the bed. Only stay in the deluxe rooms. Our family had 1 deluxe room and 2 standard rooms, and the standard rooms were tiny and our tiny shower was very moldy and almost too small to function. We were fortunate to be able to upgrade to a deluxe room for our remaining 3 nights. The staff was very accommodating, helpful and friendly. We especially enjoyed the breakfast staff - an older gentleman in particular was lovely to our family. They are helpful with the terrace bar, and we enjoyed that immensely. The desk staff helped us with maps, restaurant suggestions, tram information, and museum information. The location is perfect for visitors and within walking distance to many sites. We had a personal tour guide for a day (which was wonderful) and he mentioned that this particular area in Istanbul has very small standard hotel rooms and that he always recommends deluxe rooms to tourists - no matter what hotel. We will definitely stay at this hotel again next year - but only in deluxe rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful but flawed”
Reviews.Author: 910Critic
Reviews.Content: Staying at the Ibrahim Pasha made for a mixed experience. The downstairs seating area is lovely and very comfortable. The breakfast is delicious and the breakfast staff very nice. Front desk staff are generally nice too. You get a lovely view of the Blue Mosque from the pretty terrace upstairs. The double rooms are very small for two people, the larger ones range from gorgeous to just attractive. We stayed in a medium-sized larger room. Everything looked great - minimalist, with a touch of Ottoman style in the sofas, cushions etc. But I noticed after unpacking that the toilet in our bathroom had not been cleaned before we moved in. It had some very unpleasant stains around the bowl and on the rim from previous occupants, which I ended up cleaning myself. Stupid perhaps, but I didn't want to start things off on a complaining note. Sadly though this was symptomatic of the way the rooms were tended (or not). All the room attendant seemed to do was make the bed and clean out the trash. They didn't clean the bath/shower, change the towels or dust (there was also a layer of dust on arrival). The marble bath leaked each time we had a bath or shower. The fan in the bathroom didn't work. The hotel also experienced major leaks after a couple of heavy rains. One guy on our floor had his one pair of shoes filled with rainwater leaking into his room from the roof. The hotel seems to think it can survive on its reputation for cool, and doesn't need to make an effort when it comes to the details (and cleanliness is really more than a detail). That's not acceptable when you're paying somewhere between 120 and 175 euros depending on the room.

Reviews.Title: “This slips into my top ten...easily.”
Reviews.Author: GeorgeGB
Reviews.Content: Having accepted that the old quarter of istanbul was the place to stay (first good decision) and then realised the Four Seasons was fully booked (except for suites at a huge cost) it was a bit of a task to hit on something that would push my buttons. The Ibrahim Pasha, I discovered ,provided all I could have wished for and even the lack of a bathtub did not make me unhappy. With the hotels assistance we had a car waiting at the airport and a swift transfer soon had us weaving through the streets of Sulthanamet and to our home for 5 nights. The hotel lobby,Library/sitting room, Breakfast Room is a mix of styles beautifully eclectic mix of modern/art deco/roccoco with touches of 'shabby chic' absolutely brilliantly executed....this not ,I stress, 'designer' lead it is someones careful hand with a flair for understated interior furnishing. The curving (old) marble staircase leading on to encaustic tiles around a light well lit centrally from glass tiles which themselves form part of a roof terrace are all I assume original and then adapted features. Our Deluxe room (room 305) in the newly created extension ( it was 2 days before we realised that it was an extension,it was so skillfully done!) had a solid light oak floor an open walk in wardrobe with plenty of hanging space and shelves to leave suitcases for easy access. The small window alongside the double bed opened for air if you didn't want to use the air con and the huge foor to ceiling widow at the sitting area end of the room had an intrigueing sliding mechanism that allowed acces onto our open balcony from where we had a very close view of the museum wall (which we liked because it had interesting architectural features) and also a view of the Blue Mosque,despite the room wall being 75% window it was extremely private. The marble shower room was ultra modern and had a rainfall shower and other superb chrome fittings and another window , the lighting in all areas had been carefully considered and could be dimmed to suit the mood.The Flat screen T V was centrally situated on a single chrome post and could be rotated for viewing in either the sitting area or whilst in bed,to my wifes delight she could find several french game shows !.Fresh fruit was left out each day. Breakfast was a good experience and I enjoyed the crunchy muesli with yoghurt and honey followed by bread and jam with cake and terrific coffee,orange juice is extra but it is the best ever and the glasses are huge. The breakfast staff are hugely efficient and seem to anticipate what you want,there has been criticism on tripadvisor about the older member of the breakfast staff but I cannot understand why this is so,perhaps he's not 'chatty' enough or he seems preoccupied,however one must realise that he is trying to feed and water hotel guests that can turn up anytime between 7pm and 11pm, I am embarrassed to say that ONE BRITISH guest arrived at the same time we did, comandeered two much needed tables for herself her husband and two travelling companions despite her husband not appearing until 15 minutes later and her travelling companions not having appeared by the time we had eaten a leisurely breakfast returned to our room to change and then set out for the day.Try organising people like that and keeping cheerful ! This has been a long review,I know ,nevertheless I still cannot express how well this establishment fitted our needs,I could have stayed much much longer.

Reviews.Title: “Quaint and boutique really means small and ordinary plus inconsiderate host”
Reviews.Author: Springer8
Reviews.Content: We stayed at th Ibrahim Pasha in June 2008 and booked the hotel after seeing their website which on comparison to real life is somewhat liberal in its portrayal. The public areas of the hotel were not a true representation of what was shown on the website and the room was very small, above a noisy street. At a daily rate of 125 euros grossly over priced even for a major city. But the worse aspect of our stay was the construction work being undertaken and the constant drilling and hammering going on throughout the day. Ok you are out most of the day exploring a wonderful vibrant and cultural city and when you get back you want to get your head down for an hour or so but not here, impossible with the building noise going on. We 'put up with it' for 2 days but on the third I went to reception to air my views. After I asked for the manager who did not understand what I was talking about I was approached whom I understood to be by the principal/owner. He was most inconsiderate saying that 'construction work cannot be stopped and must go on.' I said at least they should advise guests when they are booking that construction work is in progress, he was not even apologetic and my opinion should not be in position working directly with the public. This was our last day of three and my regret is that we did not leave then but stayed and paid them another 125 euros. I would suggest that prospective guests think seriously about whether they should consider thinking about this hotel. I have stayed many times in various parts of Turkey and in my opinion this has been my only poor and disappointing experience which I have already related to those I know who wish to go Istanbul and now to your readers. The general staff were fine and helpful. Do not let this put you off visiting Istanbul, it is a fascinating City

Reviews.Title: “Very good”
Reviews.Author: MemberTurkey
Reviews.Content: Of the Sultanahmet hotels I have stayed in this one is my favourite. The location is excellent - just across from the Sultanahmet mosque. Rooms are small but well designed and do not feel oppressive. It is clean and stylish with lovely clean, white bed linen. Bathrooms are quite small but for the area that seems quite normal. The breakfast selection is maybe smaller than in some hotels but the quality is high. Staff were polite and helpful. I would definitely stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Really liked this hotel!”
Reviews.Author: Spumone
Reviews.Content: I really liked this hotel. The rooms very very clean with crisp linen and it was in a very quiet area with a wonderful breakfast. I enjoyed the lobby room with it's fireplace going so one could have a coffee, relax and read the newspaper. The staff were attentive, polite and helpful. I would definitely come back. I enjoyed the decor of the hotel as well.

Reviews.Title: “Larger rooms only, please”
Reviews.Author: MikieSimon
Reviews.Content: This hotel is only good if you either have very little baggage or if you stay in one of the larger rooms. The smaller rooms have about half a meter between the bed and the walls. Because we were off-season, we upgraded very reasonably. The younger people are nice but the old guy who makes breakfast does not belong in a service industry. If the younger people are not around, don't ask him for anything except perhaps coffee. Good location reasonably near to the tram, but please realize you are next to the Blue Mosque's 24 speakers blaring 5 times a day beginning at 5:45 am. Best in good weather when the roof terrace is open, if you can get a seat.

Reviews.Title: “Pretty Good Hotel”
Reviews.Author: Rappongi27
Reviews.Content: Stayed for 3 days in early October 2007. This is a converted house with about 16 rooms on 4 floors. Our room (on the 2d floor) consisted of a smallish sleeping area with a queen sized bed, that was relatively hard, and a very small sitting area with a couch and a new flat screen TV. The bathroom was adequate, but had only a shower. The breakfast each day was a pretty nice buffet (hard boiled eggs, cheeses, breads, jams, cucumbers and tomatoes (you are, after all, in Turkey), fruits and cereals). Staff speaks excellent English and is very helpful/friendly. This is 1/2 block from the hypodrome, and very well located for access to Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque and other sites. It is a quick walk to the tram line if you're going farther. The only noise I heard was from a nearby school. There is no traffic noise on this small Sultanamet street. I did not have any problems with cleanliness or other issues noted by others. The room was cleaned, the towels replenished, and we had no complaints at all. I liked the hotel, except that I thought it a bit overpriced, but then, with the dollar as it is, what isn't?

Reviews.Title: “Great locatÄ±on,but poor value for money”
Reviews.Author: footloose111
Reviews.Content: Great location. Close to all the main tourist attractions.Great breakfasts & charming people. However, hard beds,rooms poorly cleaned each day,bath towels not changed daily,& very noisy from internal noise if on first floor. Dirty,stained sofa cover,& transparent shower curtain showed other users' hairs & dirt marks. in fact,bathrooms not as good as you would expect for the price (175 euro). No clock,music or radio. I applaud the vision,but execution lets it down.

Reviews.Title: “Totally Over-hyped! Small Rooms & Expensive...”
Reviews.Author: David49b
Reviews.Content: This is my third trip to Istanbul in the last fifteen years. I remember back in the early 1990s, having walked to the Ibrahim Pasha to ck it out. It was one of the first, classy boutique hotels to have opened in the historic area of the city, Sultanhamet. I vowed to stay there one day. Well, I just completed a 5 night stay, along with three friends. We all stayed in different rooms. I was in one of the small rooms for 125 Euros (US$ 175) and later on, one of the suites at 175 Euros (US$ 250). I also had a chance to see the rooms of my friends. Both category of room were tiny, as were the bathrooms, which were identical. The views from the single rooms were of a wall across the narrow street in front of the hotel. Shades had to be drawn most of the time for privacy. The suite had a view of debris-filled rooftops. So much for views! My friends and I all agreed that the breakfast was the best part of our stay. It was copious, with a wide range of pastries, yoghurt, cereals, hard-boiled eggs, breads, tomatoes, cucumbers, fruit and assorted jellies. And, it was available for several hours, in case you wanted to sleep in one day and still have breakfast. Lastly, the front desk staff were not particularly professional. They seemed to be graduate university students, rather than experienced hoteliers. (At these prices, one might expect more "spit and polish" from the front desk.) And, almost all the recommendations for restaurants, etc. were the most expensive in town, i.e. "tourist or local expense account habitues." There are many better hotels for the price charged by the Ibrahim Pasha. This hotel is coasting on its reputation and the accolades received when it first opened 13 yrs ago. If the rate were 80 Euros and 100 Euros for the suites, I'd say that would be fair. But not for what they're charging. Avoid this hotel unless you have no concept of value, there are many better value hotels around for the money.

Reviews.Title: “Location, Location, Location”
Reviews.Author: culverwood
Reviews.Content: We had two rooms here a standard for my son which he thought fine and a deluxe room 404, the one with sloping ceilings shown in the photos on their website which is on the top floor with bath and good views. It is a very small hotel in a great position a stones throw from the Blue Mosque and right in the centre of all the sights. The view from the roof terrace in the evening to the Blue Mosque and the Sea of Mamara is great. The public areas are small but there were never too many people there at once. The breakfast was very good but the freshly squeezed orange juice was extra and this was not made clear. On the other hand teas and coffees were free throughout the day. Lovely labrador

Reviews.Title: “Anniversary in Sultanahmet”
Reviews.Author: nigeandjose
Reviews.Content: My wife and I were recommended this hotel through a friend for four nights and were warned that the rooms were relatively small, but they were very nice, and more than suitable. For the most part I agree with the two earlier reviews, but would add the following. Ask for a front room as we did if you stay on school mornings, as you will be best located to avoid the noisy cheribs at the school next door. (Having said that you will be called to prayer at ungodly hours of the morning, and i defy anyone to sleep thru that!) We found the staff extremely helpful and very friendly, when welcoming you and when you engage them, but otherwise they leave you to your devices and to be at home relaxing in the hotel. The fire is great, and nothing stops you from ripping the head off a bottle of wine or two in front of the fire. We also used the hotels recommendations for restaurants and weren't disappointed! We also felt that it was a great location for walking to all sights, restaurants and in general. Enjoy.

Reviews.Title: “Very cosy and welcoming”
Reviews.Author: fluffyloveheart
Reviews.Content: Overall I loved the Ibrahim Pasha Hotel; we went for new years celebrations and the weather was bitterly cold but the lovely roaring fire in the reception area gave us a lovley welcome. The staff were knowledgable and gave us a good introduction to the area, they were happy to give information whenever we needed any but they weren't very friendly generally. The rooms were nicely decorated in typical traditional turkish stlyle which i liked but we warned they were extremely small. If you are a large couple opt for somewhere else. Also there isnt much storage space so if you are staying for longer than a few days you might find this frustrating. Locationwise the hotel was great for all the sights, we were a stones throw from the blue mosque, hagia sofia, the grand bazaar and the palace but if you want to go shopping or are looking for night life you need to get taxis across the golden horn where things are a bit more bustling. The breakfast was typically Turkish and consisted of boiled eggs, bread, olives, cucumber etc. It was fine but nothing special. In short I really loved my stay and would recommend this hotel for people that are there to see the sights rather than shop and party.

Reviews.Title: “Cosy and super-friendly boutique hotel”
Reviews.Author: chacann
Reviews.Content: This is a small property in a quiet location just up the hill from the Blue Mosque - run by two very helpful gentlemen who look like brothers, but aren't. Lovely open fire just inside the front door, with comfortable chairs and lots of reading matter - a nice way to thaw out on a winter's evening, with drinks served. Standard rooms are very small but nicely finshed with fruit and a mini-safe. It might be best to seek the "suite" rooms, which provide a bit more space to move around. Free wi-fi was good for the first day but then stopped working.... Their restaurant recommendations were excellent, they also provide useful recommendations for walking tours, the main sights are all nearby. Breakfast was simple, no fruit included...fresh orange juice cost Lira5 extra! Transfer from the airport provided by the hotel cost Euro20 and was adequate, the van was an external contract and rather basic. The best deal came from booking direct and they provided 10% discount for Euro cash payment. We liked the hotel and the service, but our room really was small....The open-area facilities helped make up for it and the roof top patio must be wonderful in the summer.

Reviews.Title: “Real value of hotel shows when we get in trouble”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: The quality of hotel is usually evaluated by such factors as location, room amenity, price, etc. No doubt, Ibrahim Pasha Hotel is of a satisfactory standard in these respects. Especially, the location is excellent for sightseeing as well as business purpose. But, the real value of this hotel is in its kind hospitality. I was mistaken about the departure time of my returning flight and found it 1 hour before at the hotel. I was totally panicked. Then, the hotel staffs called to the airline company and asked a taxi driver to hurry up to the airport. With their help, I could arrive in time and catch the flight at the last straw. I do not forget their kind support. I believe that the real value of hotel shows when we get in trouble.

Reviews.Title: “Never Again!”
Reviews.Author: glamcatster
Reviews.Content: If you would like an overpriced, inauthentic hotel then you might not mind this hotel as much as we did. Booked for 4 days and thankfully, checked out after 2. There was zero Turkish charm, the staff was unfriendly with minimal effort to be helpful. The rooftop was dirty and not maintained with an obstructed view. We moved to a great hotel with lovely employees, beautiful rooftop. A place that added to the charm of istanbul rather than distracted from it like Ibrahim Pasha Hotel.

Reviews.Title: “We loved it!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the IP for 5 days. The hotel was really lovely. It had more of a BB feel to it and was definitely more on the quiet side. The staff was very helpful and spoke very good English. The rooms were small but,you certainly did not feel like you were in a "coffin". The room was nicely decorated and very clean. Plus they gave you a tray of fresh fruit every day. For you hipsters out there this is a great hotel but, it is not in the most liviest district that the city has to offer but, you are a short cab ride away from everything. For you hardcore tourist your are a 5 minute walk to the Cistern, Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia and Topkapi Palace!! It's fabulous. Also, the hotel does a nice cold breakfast buffet be warned though the fresh squeeze OJ (which is delightful) will cost you 5YTL. Also, they do not have an iron so, if you need to press something you will need to bring your own travel iron or have them send it to the laundry. TesekkÃ¼r ederim!

Reviews.Title: “Great but expensive”
Reviews.Author: Justanothermember
Reviews.Content: I stayed at the Ibrahim Pasha for three nights before switching to a cheaper hotel for the remainder of my stay in Istanbul. I loved the Ibrahim Pasha and found it very charming throughout, from the rooftop terrace to the cozy fireside lounge area to the coffeehouse-like breakfast room. My room had lovely decor, a flat-screen TV, complimentary fruit, and a complimentary Time Out Istanbul magazine. Breakfast was a cold buffet but very good and varied. The staff was helpful and knowledgeable and spoke good English (Al Italia had lost my luggage, and the staff was wonderful about making calls to the airline). Limited Internet use is free on a laptop in the breakfast room. I found the location excellent, on a small, quiet street right off the main tourist drag where the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia are. The downside: The Ibrahim Pasha is a splurge, considering you can find totally adequate hotels for half the price, or less. In addition, my room was quite small (partly because they packed in two leather side chairs). It was perfectly great for me as a solo traveler, but for a couple (especially large people, or those with much baggage) it would likely be a bit tight. The bathroom was tiny; you could not get to the toilet without closing the door.

Reviews.Title: “Exceedingly Charming and perfect location”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: What a great hotel- very charming, very friendly staff who all speak perfect English, nice food, and rooms to a high standard including flat screen TVs. Rooms can be small, but are very clean and very comfortable. The location is perfect- just 2 blocks from the Blue Mosque and 3 blocks from the Hagia Sophia. The lobby areas are also very comfortable and furnished to a high standard. Can't recommend this hotel highly enough and if I return to Istanbul one day I would definitely stay at the Ibrahim Pasha again.

Reviews.Title: “An overpriced coffin”
Reviews.Author: ridem
Reviews.Content: We had booked in for 14 days.We arrived to find a room so small that 2 people and 2 suitcases filled the entire room. We were promised a better room, but when time came to change it was suddenly "already booked". We left on the 3rd day. This hotel is grossly overpriced. The management is dodgy. There are hundreds of hotels in the neighborhood with equally nice roof top lounges and decent breakfasts. Shabby treatment for a hotel that was less than half full in late autumn. This hotel was the worse experience in over 6 months of travel in Turkey-where we pre-booked many of our hotels and were satisfied. This place is cruising totally on its guide book plaudits. It fails to deliver.

Reviews.Title: “Loved the Ibrahim Pasha”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We loved this hotel. It is in the old part of town within walking distance of most attractions. The staff was friendly and helpful. Many nights lodgers stayed by the fire in the lobby to read or have a drink and discuss their day's adventures. The only downsides are that most of the good restraunts are in a different part of town, about a 15 min cab ride away (and in an area I would not like to stay in) and the showers are small and somewhat rustic. However, the lovely minimalist decor and the wonderful staff more than make up for these issues. We highly recommend this hotel. Do go to the rooftop for tea and lovely views of the local mosques.

Reviews.Title: “Location, Hospitality and Comfort”
Reviews.Author: Pensor
Reviews.Content: I recently stayed at this hotel for two nights for business travel. As most of the other positive reviewers have responded I can concur that this centrally located hotel lives up to its standards as a true boutique establishment. Upon arrival, having to conduct a small business transaction in the main lounge area I was greeted with some warm Turkish tea for myself and a business associate by the front desk representative who also offered translation assistance. I found the colors and setting in this room as elsewhere in the hotel pleasant and soothing to the eye. I compliment the hotel on its excellent room furnishings (I used two during my stay) and the striking green and red color design. In the morning an excellent breakfast buffet spread was put out that I found both nutritious and delicious including yogurt, cheeses, sweetbreads, olives cereals, coffee and fresh orange juice. I found myself in a bit of a credit dilemma as my American bank had put a hold against my credit card suspecting suspicious activity as I was outside of the U.S. I was able to obtain a temporary loan from the front desk staff which was a great relief until my credit situation was resolved. On the rooftop I can remember a wonderful escaping moment at dusk with the excellent view of the nearby Blue Mosque as the lights strung around the Minarets lit . The even closer Hippodrome and nearby shops I found busy with activity, always offering new something for the eye to behold. I would highly recommend this hotel to others.
